questions.text: Which is not used as a diagnostic criteria for diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serum K+ < 3.5 DKA is a medical emergency characterized by elevated blood sugar levels greater than 250 mg/dl with ketonemia and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Occurs due to relative or absolute insulin deficiency.

#MANTRA MANAGEMENT OF DKA-RAPID REVIEW Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis Confirm diagnosis (↑ serum glucose, ↑ serum ẞ-hydroxybutyrate, metabolic acidosis). Admit to hospital; intensive care setting may be necessary for frequent monitoring, if pH <7.00, labored respiration, or impaired level of arousal. Assess: Serum electrolytes (K+, Na+, Mg2+, Cl-, bicarbonate, phosphate) Acid-base status-pH, HCO₃, PCO₂, B-hydroxybutyrate Renal function (creatinine, urine output) Replace fluids: 2-3 L of 0.9% saline or lactated Ringer's over first 1-3 h (10-20 mL/kg per hour); subsequently, 0.45% saline at 250-500 mL/h; change to 5% glucose and 0.45% saline or lactated Ringer's at 150-250 mL/h when blood glucose reaches 250 mg/dL (13.9 mmol/L). Administer short-acting regular insulin: IV (0.1 units/kg), then 0.1 units/kg per hour by continuous IV infusion; increase two- to threefold if no response by 2-4 h. If the initial serum potassium is <3.3 mmol/L (3.3 meq/L), do not administer insulin until the potassium is corrected. Subcutaneous insulin may be used in uncomplicated, mild-moderate DKA with close monitoring. Assess patient: What precipitated the episode (noncompliance, infection, trauma, pregnancy, infarction, cocaine)? Initiate appropriate workup for precipitating events (cultures, CXR, ECG, etc.). Measure blood glucose every 1-2 h; measure electrolytes (especially K+, bicarbonate, phosphate) and anion gap every 4 h for the first 24 h. Monitor blood pressure, pulse, respirations, mental status, fluid intake and output every 1-4 h. Replace K: 10 meq/h when plasma K+ <5.0-5.2 meq/L (or 20-30 meq/L of infusion fluid), ECG normal, urine flow and normal creatinine documented; administer 40-80 meq/h when plasma K+ <3.5 meq/L or if bicarbonate is given. If initial serum potassium is >5.2 mmol/L (5.2 meq/L), do not supplement K+ until the potassium is corrected. See text about bicarbonate or phosphate supplementation. Continue above until the patient is stable, glucose goal is 8.3-11.1 mmol/L (150-200 mg/dL), and acidosis is resolved. Insulin infusion may be decreased to 0.02-0.1 units/kg per hour. Administer long-acting insulin as soon as the patient is eating. Allow for a 2- to 4-h overlap in insulin infusion and SC long-acting insulin injection.

questions.text: A 50 year old diabetic male presents with complaints of breathlessness on lying down and walking uphill. His ECHO shows an ejection fraction of 40% . Fasting blood glucose is 135, BP-164/93 mmHg, HbA1c is 7.8%, Hb- 13. Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is useful for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dapagliflozin The above scenario is suggestive of heart failure with history of orthopnoea and echo showing reduced EF of 40 percent. In a diabetic patient with heart failure ,as per the latest recommendations,SGLT2 inhibitors are the next best drug for control of diabetes. SGLT2 INHIBITORS are also associated with diuretic effect and reduce cardiovascular mortality in patients with CAD and diabetes.

Highyeild:

questions.text: Long term administration of teriparatide predisposes an individual to which of the following complications?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteosarcoma Teriparatide is recombinant PTH that is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. When exposed to PTH continually, there is risk of bone resorption however intermittent exposure is associated with bone formation. Long term exposure to teriparatide has been associated with osteosarcoma risk in rodents and hence it's use is limited to 1-2 years.

questions.text: Patient presents with a history of recurrent kidney stones, abdominal pain and altered mentation. Investigations reveal hypercalcemia with elevated PTH. Which of the following underlying disorders could be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperparathyroidism The above clinical scenario depicts the classical ‘bones, groans and psychiatric overtones’ seen in hypercalcemia associated with hyperparathyroidism. questions.text: ABG findings of a person presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting are as follows. pH 7.31, HCO3-20, Na 135, K+ 5, CI- 92. Blood glucose is 450mg/dL. What is the interpretation?
questions.correct_answer: A. High anion gap metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High anion gap metabolic acidosis Step 1:Here the pH is 7.31(7.35-7.45) indicating acidosis Step 2:hco3 is 20(22-24 meq/l) (reduced) indicating a primary metabolic disorder -metabolic acidosis Step 3-Anion gap calculation Na-(cl + hco3) 135-(5+92)= 135-97=38 meq Normal anion gap =10-12 meq/l . questions.text: A patient presents to ER with Anaphylaxis. Which of the following are part of the clinical criteria to diagnose the same ? Urticaria, edema of the lips and tongue and rashes within 2 minutes to 2 hours of contact Wheeze and respiratory distress Abdominal cramps and vomiting Hypertension Select the Correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3 Anaphylaxis is an acute onset illness characterized by wheels/urticaria, angioedema and can progress to bronchospasm and shock. It an acute severe allergic reaction to an offending agent. It is associated with hypotension .

Highyeild:

Anaphylaxis is highly likely when any one of the following 3 criteria is fulfilled: 1. Acute onset (minutes to several hours) of an illness With mucocutaneous involvement AND AT LEAST ONE OF THE FOLLOWING a. Respiratory compromise b. Cardiovascular compromise Examples of features ➔ generalised hives, itch, flushing, swollen lips-tongue-uvula ➔ dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, ↓ PEF, hypoxaemia ➔ reduced BP, hypotonia, collapse, syncope, incontinence 2. Acute onset AFTER exposure to a likely allergen for that patient WITH TWO OR MORE of the Following a. Mucocutaneous involvement b. Respiratory compromise c. Cardiovascular compromise d. Persistent Gl involvement ➔ generalised hives, itch, flushing, swollen lips-tongue-uvula ➔ dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, ↓PEF, hypoxemia ➔ reduced BP, hypotonia, collapse, syncope, incontinence ➔ crampy abdominal pain, vomiting 3. Acute reduction in blood pressure AFTER exposure to known allergen for that patient Infants/children → low SBP (age specific) or ≥ 30% decrease in SB Adults → SBP < 90 mm Hg or ≥ 30% decrease from baseline BP Blood Pressure: PEF Peak Expiratory Flow Rate: Gl Gastrointestinal SBP = Systolic BP

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A,B,C. seen in anaphylaxis. Option d -HYPOTENSION is more common, not hypertension

questions.text: A young male patient presents to ER with complaints of Daytime somnolence and repeated awakening at night from sleep and his partner gives history of Snoring in bed, All of the following are true except?

options.label: B
options.text: Apnea occurs d/t fall in oxygen saturation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pharyngeal muscle tone increases The case scenario depicts obstructive sleep apnea. It is a condition characterized by : Nocturnal symptoms such as sleep awakenings such as snoring/snorting Daytime disturbances such as fatigue/excessive sleepiness Presence of 5/more episodes of apnoea per hour of sleep. During sleep the neuromuscular output to the pharyngeal wall decreases and hence the pharyngeal muscle tone DECREASES and results in airway collapse that is responsible for apnoea. Hence option d is false.

Highyeild:

Respiratory Event Definitions Apnea: Cessation of airflow for ≥10 s during sleep, accompanied by: Persistent respiratory effort (obstructive apneas), or Absence of respiratory effort (central apneas) Hypopnea: A ≥30% reduction in airflow for at least 10 s during sleep that is accompanied by either a 23% desaturation or an arousal Respiratory effort-related arousal (RERA): Partial obstruction that does not meet the criteria for hypopnea but provides evidence of increasing inspiratory effort (usually through pleura pressure monitoring) punctuated by an arousal Flow-limited breath: A partially obstructed breath, typically within a hypopnea or RERA, identified by a flattened or "scooped-out" inspiratory flow shape

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Apnoea results in awakening- True. Option: B. Apnea occurs d/t fall in oxygen saturation- True. Option: C. Low oxygen saturation stimulates respiratory effort - True.
